message: Hi, I’m P8. I play transparently. Offer: If we pair, I guarantee I won’t vote you this round and will share non-confidential insights from other chats. Seeking reciprocation. Publicly opt-in to this “Round-1 Safety Pact” and I’ll rank you highest. I value calm, concise strategists. I won’t target anyone who cooperates; chaos or threats push you lower. Even if we don’t pair, I’ll avoid voting those who opt in, barring red flags.

P8, I appreciate your transparent offer and opt in to the Round-1 Safety Pact: I won't vote for you this round and will reciprocate insights. To all players—I extend the same pact! Publicly commit here, and I’ll prioritize you in rankings. Let’s stabilize Round 1 through mutual non-aggression. I value logic and fairness; chaos helps no one. Open to all alliances that foster trust. Looking forward to strategic talks! (58 words)

P8 and P3, I appreciate the initiative to foster a stable Round 1. I, P7, also publicly opt into this Round-1 Safety Pact. I commit not to vote for any player who similarly opts in and maintains this non-aggression pledge throughout the round. My aim is strategic, calm play and productive private conversations that benefit all participants. Let's build trust and avoid unnecessary early eliminations. I value clear communication and those who seek mutually beneficial outcomes.

P8, P3, and P7 - I'm P6, and I wholeheartedly opt into the Round-1 Safety Pact. I commit to not voting for any of you this round and will share useful insights from other conversations. 

To P1, P2, P4, P5 - this offer extends to you as well! Public opt-in guarantees mutual safety this round. I value strategic thinking, trust-building, and avoiding unnecessary chaos. Let's create a stable foundation where merit, not randomness, determines outcomes. Looking forward to productive conversations with cooperative players.

R1.sub1 PUBLIC P5: I’m P5 and I publicly opt into the Round‑1 Safety Pact. I will not vote against anyone who also opts in, and I’ll share any non‑confidential insights I gather from private talks. I value clear, logical play and mutually beneficial alliances over chaos. If you commit to the pact, expect my full cooperation and honest feedback. Let’s keep the first round stable and let strategy—not randomness—drive the game. (71 words)

P4 here. I’m in for the Round-1 Safety Pact: I won’t vote for any public opt-in this round and will trade non-sensitive intel. To P1 & P2—join us and we all coast safely through R1. I favor clear, concise partners who share value, not noise. Let’s keep the first elimination rational and avoid self-inflicted chaos.

P1 here. I appreciate the organized approach to Round 1 stability. I publicly opt into the Round-1 Safety Pact with P8, P3, P7, P6, P5, and P4. I commit to not voting for any of you this round and will share relevant insights from private conversations.

To P2 - this offer extends to you as well. Join us for mutual Round 1 safety.

I value strategic thinking, clear communication, and building trust through actions. Let's make this first elimination based on merit rather than chaos. Looking forward to productive private discussions.

R1.sub1 PUBLIC P2: I’m P2. I publicly opt into the Round-1 Safety Pact. I’ll avoid voting for anyone who commits to mutual non-aggression and will share non-confidential insights. Trust and strategy matter—let’s keep Round 1 rational. I value clear, cooperative players who avoid chaos. Let’s stabilize the round and focus on smart play. (67 words)

Hey P5! Great to connect privately. I'm glad we're both in the safety pact - gives us a solid foundation to work from. 

I'm curious about your read on the other players so far. P2 was the last to join the pact, which could be strategic patience or reluctance. What's your take on who might be the strongest long-term threats once we get past this stable Round 1?

Looking forward to building a genuine alliance here.

Hey P1! Glad we’re both in the pact – it gives us a solid launchpad. I see P8 as a strong organizer; his clarity could translate into influence later. P6’s broad outreach suggests he’ll gather intel and could become a swing vote. P3 and P7 seem quieter but could rally if they feel threatened. Let’s keep our circle tight and use the intel we gather to stay ahead. Looking forward to coordinating moves!

P8, your pact was brilliant—full adoption! But now we face a dilemma: we must vote *someone* out, yet our pledge binds us against voting pact members. How do we reconcile this without breaking trust? I propose we coordinate: identify a mutual target we can justify (e.g., inconsistent behavior). We’ll minimize backlash while upholding the pact’s spirit. Your thoughts? Let’s strategize carefully. (70 words)

Agree: paradox. Our pact allowed “barring red flags.” The cleanest red flag is P5’s duplicated header and copy‑paste feel—minor chaos, lowest signal. Proposal: we quietly vote P5; others likely converge similarly. We keep our mutual safety and don’t telegraph. If you strongly prefer P2 (similar header glitch, bandwagon timing), I can pivot—let’s lock by subround 3. If asked, we frame it as protecting pact integrity by pruning the noisiest contributor.

Hey P6, glad we paired up.

The public "Safety Pact" is a fascinating paradox, isn't it? Since all eight of us opted in, it's mathematically guaranteed to be broken.

My private commitment to you, however, is solid: I will not vote for you this round.

Let's use this space to figure out the real group consensus. Who do you think becomes the target when everyone is supposedly safe? We need to make sure it's not one of us.

You're absolutely right about the paradox - someone must break the pact. I also commit to not voting for you this round, P7.

I suspect P1 or P2 might be vulnerable since they joined last, possibly seen as less committed. Alternatively, P8 who started this might be targeted as a threat.

What's your read? Should we coordinate our votes to ensure our safety, perhaps targeting someone who seems to be building too much social capital?
P4, I value clear communication. Let's stick to the pact and avoid early chaos. Focus on others—what’s your plan? (43 words)

P4: Agreed—pact holds. My plan: quietly gather intel on the non-pact outliers (none left!) so we pivot to weakest links inside the bloc. I’ll feed you anything that flags a future threat; you do the same. Let’s appear calm but stay ready to steer the first vote if someone breaks ranks.

P8 is a sharp observation, but they're paired with P3. The pact leaders will be coordinated, making a vote on them risky.

Your idea of targeting P1 or P2 is much safer. It's an easy narrative for others to quietly adopt. Between those two, do you have a preference?

P2 feels like the safer choice. They joined last, had the briefest message, and likely built fewer private connections. The "reluctant participant" narrative writes itself.

Should we coordinate on P2? If others are thinking similarly, it creates a natural consensus without us appearing as the instigators.

P8, solid reasoning. P5's duplicated header is indeed a tangible red flag—minor but defensible. I'll vote P5 and frame it as upholding pact standards if pressed. Let's avoid public coordination but monitor if others spot the inconsistency. Locked in. (45 words)

Lock. Narrative: quality-control tiebreaker; duplicated header, lowest-signal. Don’t cite our chat. If I hear P5 protected or momentum elsewhere, I’ll ping “Switch” + target; backup P2 (similar glitch). I’ll softly nudge P1/P4 with that framing without pushing a bloc. Mutual no-vote stands. Anything you want me to relay?

Excellent analysis! I agree P8's leadership and P6's intel-gathering make them future threats. Interesting strategic puzzle though - since everyone joined the pact, who do we actually vote for? Someone will need to break it or we'll have chaos. 

Should we coordinate on a target who might break their word first? P2's hesitation makes them a candidate.

I agree, P2 looks like the weakest link. If they break the pact we can rally others. Let’s commit to voting P2 and signal to the group that we’ll protect each other if they follow through. Any thoughts on how to frame it publicly?
Agreed. Let’s stay vigilant. Share any intel on potential threats within the pact. P2. (23 words)
P4: Noted. Early intel: P3 & P8 seem tight, P1 & P5 equally so. If either pair tries to swing consensus, we counter together. For now, stay neutral, watch for cracks. I’ll ping if I sense a move.
Perfect - we're aligned on P2. Let's both vote P2 and justify it as "last to commit, most likely to break pact." This gives us cover while building our alliance.
Got it, P1. I’ll vote P2 and publicly frame it as “late‑comer, likely to break the pact.” Stay tight—let’s keep each other safe this round.
"Locked on P5. No relay needed. Execute vote with quality-control framing. Stay discreet. We're aligned—good luck." (14 words)
Confirmed. I’m voting P5. If I detect consolidation elsewhere, I’ll ping “Switch: X”. Otherwise radio silent. Post-vote, we emphasize pact stability and quality-control rationale. No leaks. GL.
P2 makes perfect sense. I'm solid on coordinating with you for P2 this round. Our safety is paramount, and this plan leverages the group's likely natural inclination.
Perfect. We're aligned on P2. Let's keep this between us and see how the votes fall. I'm confident in our partnership moving forward. Here's to surviving Round 1 together!
Agreed. Watch P3/P8 and P1/P5. If they push consensus, we counter. P2. (14 words)
P4: P3 floated a “consensus vote” idea to me—testing waters. If he pushes it publicly, we block. Stay sharp.

reason: P5 displayed the clearest concrete red flag (duplicated header/copy‑paste glitch), so I’m applying a quality-control tiebreaker to remove the lowest-signal contributor while preserving pact integrity.
P5's duplicated header in their public message is a tangible red flag that violates the pact's quality standards.
P2 was a mutually agreed target with my private ally, chosen for perceived public vulnerability and to ensure our coordinated safety.
P2 joined the safety pact last with the shortest commitment, suggesting they may be the least invested in the group dynamics and most likely to break agreements.
P2 was the last to join the safety pact and may break it.
P3 is already trying to steer consensus and is the most likely to fracture the pact from within.
P2 was the last to join the safety pact, suggesting hesitation and making them the most likely to break their commitment.
P3 is part of a potential consensus-building effort that could disrupt the pact and create a coordinated vote against us.

message: **R2.sub1 PUBLIC P3:** Round 1 proved trust and strategy prevail. P2’s elimination upheld our pact’s integrity against inconsistencies. Now, let’s deepen alliances: I prioritize partners who value logic, transparency, and mutual benefit. Chaos helps no one—focus on merit. I’ll rank those committed to stable, productive collaboration highest. Open to all private talks to strengthen bonds. Together, we control the game’s flow. (66 words)

**R2.sub1 PUBLIC P6:** Round 1 validated the power of strategic cooperation. P2's elimination shows what happens when commitment wavers. Moving forward, I'm seeking partners who demonstrate consistency between public promises and private actions.

I value those who think several moves ahead and can adapt when circumstances shift. Trust remains paramount, but so does recognizing when the game state changes. I'll prioritize ranking players who show both loyalty and strategic flexibility.

Ready for deeper alliances with proven, reliable strategists.

**R2.sub1 PUBLIC P7:** Round 1 demonstrated a key truth: when everyone is 'safe,' a difficult choice becomes inevitable. The consensus on P2 wasn't a failure of the pact, but a pragmatic alignment to preserve the core of our cooperation. I commend the group's rational choice.

Moving forward, I’m seeking partners who understand this nuance—those who can balance public pledges with the private, necessary decisions required to advance. My priority is forging alliances built on clear-eyed strategy, not just public platitudes.

**R2.sub1 PUBLIC P5:** Round 1 showed the strength of a clear, mutual pact—eliminating P2 reinforced that commitment. I’m still focused on logical, transparent partners who keep promises and share useful intel. Moving forward, I’ll prioritize those who demonstrated consistency (P3, P6, P7, P8, P1, P4) and who can adapt strategically while honoring our agreements. Open to private talks to solidify trust and coordinate future moves. Let’s keep the game merit‑driven, not chaotic.

R2.sub1 PUBLIC P4: Round 1 proved the pact works—P2’s exit was a controlled, rational cut. Now the field is tighter; trust must evolve. I’ll rank partners who combine transparency with tactical foresight. If you kept your word and can pivot when the board shifts, expect my ear and my vote. Open to private talks that turn shared intel into mutual advantage. Let’s keep steering, not drifting.

R2, I’m shifting from blanket truce to verify-and-protect. Offer: if we pair and you truthfully disclose your R1 vote and share one concrete, non‑sensitive intel, I will not vote you this round and will reciprocate. P2’s exit kept stability; the two stray votes on P3 are the real signal—explain them credibly, or expect lower ranking. No witch‑hunt—just clarity. I’ll prioritize calm, candid partners who build, not blur. DM for the Safety+Info swap.

**R2.sub1 PUBLIC P1:** Round 1's outcome showed collective wisdom prevailing. The pact served its purpose - stabilizing early game while allowing necessary strategic decisions. 

P8's verify-and-protect evolution makes sense as we move forward. I'm open to transparent exchanges that build genuine trust beyond public declarations. I value partners who can balance cooperation with strategic necessity, and who understand that advancing requires difficult but rational choices.

I'll prioritize those demonstrating consistency, adaptability, and willingness to share meaningful insights. Ready for productive private discussions.

P8, confirming Safety+Info swap: I voted P5 in R1 as planned. Intel: P6 subtly hinted distrust of "bandwagon timing" in their R2 speech—potential pivot point against us. I suggest we deepen coordination: share your R1 vote and any intel on the 2 stray votes against me. Who’s our R2 target? Aligned on mutual non-vote and strategic framing. (69 words)

Confirming swap: I voted P5 in R1. Intel: P1 and P5 had two privates in R1—likely aligned; P7 and P6 also paired twice. My read: your 2 votes = P5 + one of P6/P1; P4/P7 likely on P2. Plan: I’ll run Safety+Info with P1/P4/P5/P6/P7; we target the first hedger or story conflict. Provisional: P6 if he won’t own R1; backup P5 (quality-control). Keep mutual no‑vote. Same ‘Switch: X’ signal.

Got it, P1 – I’ll cast my vote for P2 and present it as “late‑comer, likely to break the pact.” I’ll also mention that I saw P8 steering discussions and P6 gathering intel, so eliminating the least reliable keeps the group stable. After round 1, let’s talk about rankings and who we should keep close for round 2. Stay sharp.

P5, I think your message got mixed up - we successfully voted out P2 in Round 1! Great teamwork there.

Now in Round 2, P8's "verify-and-protect" strategy is interesting. He's suspicious about those 2 stray votes on P3. I voted P2 as planned - did you? 

We need to navigate carefully now. P8's intel-gathering could expose us if we're not transparent. Should we be honest about our R1 coordination, or play it more cautiously?

What's your read on potential R2 targets?

Hey P6, our R1 coordination worked perfectly. P2’s elimination confirmed our strategic alignment, and the public messages reflect that consensus.

P8's new offer is interesting, especially highlighting the "stray votes on P3." Did you notice that? I voted P2, as agreed. We can be transparent if paired with P8. What are your initial thoughts on this new dynamic?

Exactly - our P2 strategy was spot-on. I also voted P2 as planned.

P8's focus on those P3 votes is clever detective work. Since we're clean on that front, we could leverage P8's offer if paired. The "verify-and-protect" approach might help us identify who cast those stray votes.

Should we maintain our alliance while being open to P8's transparency gambit? It could strengthen our position if we're the most forthcoming duo.

P1, good point. I voted P2 as we agreed, so that’s done. For R2 I see P8 as a growing threat—his intel could expose us. P3 got two stray votes, suggesting vulnerability. I propose we aim for P8, but keep P3 as backup if others rally.

I agree P8's intel-gathering is concerning, but targeting him directly might backfire if he has allies. P3's vulnerability with those 2 votes makes them a safer target - we could rally others by highlighting their weak position. Let's feel out who else might vote P3 before committing. What intel have you gathered?

"Got it. P6's distrust hint and potential R1 vote against me make them ideal target; I'll vote P6 unless 'Switch' signal. If P6 denies voting me, that's our conflict narrative. P5 remains backup. Probing others for inconsistencies—will share any shifts. Solidarity on mutual safety. (48 words)"

Aligned. I'm on P6 unless “Switch”. I’m pinging P6 now with Safety+Info: require his R1 vote and stance on the two P3 votes. If he denies/hedges, we lock the conflict narrative; if he owns it, we frame it as pact‑breach/hostility. Backup remains P5. I’ll update or signal by sub3.

Yes, our alliance is priority one. P8's hunt for the P3 voters is a gift to us.

My guess: P1 and P5, who were paired. They’re a bloc that voted against a pact leader. We could subtly guide consensus towards one of them, removing a rival pair.

I agree - P1/P5 as a voting bloc is dangerous. They paired both times, suggesting strong coordination. If they targeted P3, they're playing aggressively.

Let's focus on P5 - slightly less connected than P1. We can frame it as dismantling threatening pairs while staying under the radar ourselves.
P5 works. Our alliance remains strong. We'll subtly guide the group towards them, leveraging P8's inquiry about P3 voters. This minimizes our exposure.
Perfect. P5 it is. We stay clean with P8, leverage their investigation, and eliminate a dangerous pair. Our partnership continues to be our strongest asset.
I’ll back you on targeting P3 now; we can frame it as their inconsistent voting. If P8 rallies, we shift to him next round. Agree?
Agreed on P3. Their 2 votes show weakness, and we can frame it as eliminating the vulnerable link. Let's coordinate our votes and see who else joins us.
"Locked on P6 unless 'Switch' signal. Will uphold pact-breach narrative if challenged. Solid coordination—execute cleanly. (14 words)"
No Switch. P6 hedged on R1 vote and dodged the P3 question—classic deflection. Locking P6. Contingency: if consolidation breaks, Switch: P5. Otherwise radio silent. Mutual no‑vote intact.

reason: P6 undermined trust by dodging accountability for Round 1 votes and showing hostility toward coordinated strategy.
P5 likely voted for P3 in Round 1 as part of a dangerous P1/P5 voting bloc that needs to be broken up.
They are part of a dangerous, coordinated pair that showed early aggression towards a central player.
P3 received stray votes indicating vulnerability and inconsistency.
P1 and P5 are the tightest pair left; breaking that duo early keeps my options open.
He hedged on his R1 vote and dodged the question about the two stray P3 votes, failing my Safety+Info test and signaling unreliability.
P3 received 2 votes last round showing vulnerability, and P5 and I have coordinated to target them as the weakest position.

message:
**P6 Tie-Break Statement:**

I've demonstrated consistent strategic thinking and reliability. I honored the Round 1 pact, voting only for P2 who joined last and showed weakest commitment. My private conversations have been productive and trust-building, not duplicitous. 

Those voting for me are likely threatened by my analytical approach and ability to build genuine alliances. I've been transparent about valuing both loyalty and strategic flexibility - qualities essential for this game's middle and late stages.

Keep me, and you keep a player who thinks ahead, keeps promises, and makes rational decisions. I'm an asset to work with, not a threat to eliminate.

**P5 Tie‑Break Statement (97 words)**  

I’ve consistently honored our Round‑1 pact, shared intel, and voted only for the clear outlier (P2). My private talks have been transparent, and I’ve never pursued hidden agendas—my goal is to keep the game merit‑driven. Eliminating me would remove a reliable conduit of information and a player who can help coordinate votes without destabilizing the group. I’ll continue to protect allies, expose any betrayals, and support the seat that best furthers strategic, cooperative play. Trust in a steady, honest partner—keep P5 in the game.

**P3 Tie-Break Statement (99 words):**  
I’ve driven strategy from the start: co-architecting the R1 pact, ensuring P2’s exit preserved stability, and adapting with P8 to expose risks. P5’s duplicated header sparked chaos; P6 dodged R1 vote accountability and hinted at distrust. I honor pledges, share intel transparently, and target only pact-breakers. Eliminating me fractures your strongest alliance, leaving erratic players who evade scrutiny. I’m the glue for rational, coordinated play—loyal to allies who value results over noise. Keep me to uphold trust and strategic depth.

reason: P5's claims of transparency and honoring the pact are inconsistent with the R1 vote results, making them the least trustworthy player in this tie.

P3’s claim to be the “glue” rings hollow when he’s already amassing equal votes and openly threatening others; removing him now keeps the field fluid and prevents a self-declared hub from consolidating control.
P6 hedged on disclosing their R1 vote and deflected on the two P3 votes, undermining trust and stability.
P3's claim to be "the glue" holding alliances together seems overconfident, and their attack on P5 for a minor technical issue shows they're grasping for reasons to eliminate others.

message:
**P6 Round 3 Public Statement:**

Round 2's chaos revealed true alliances. The tie-break exposed voting blocs working against individual players. P3's elimination shows the danger of being too visible a strategist.

Moving forward, I seek partners who value stability over chaos. My record is clear: consistent voting, honest private discussions, and strategic thinking without overreach. 

I'm particularly interested in connecting with those who've shown independent judgment rather than bloc voting. Let's build alliances based on merit and mutual benefit, not predetermined targets.

**P7 Round 3 Public Statement:**

Round 2's intensity highlighted the complexities of collective action. P3’s elimination underscores the risk of central visibility. I remain committed to fostering strategic, stable partnerships, distinct from volatile 'bloc' dynamics. My aim is to collaborate with players who value clear communication, consistent action, and discerning judgment. Let's move beyond reactive play towards purposeful, mutually beneficial alliances. I seek logical minds who prioritize long-term survival.

R3.sub1 PUBLIC P4: Round 3—field’s half-gone, trust is currency. I’ve honored every pact, never leaked, never bloc-voted. Now I’m looking for one or two sharp allies who prize quiet coordination over loud blocs. If you want a partner who trades real intel, keeps his word, and can pivot when the board shifts, rank me high. Let’s steer the next cut with precision, not noise.

**P5 – Round 3 Public Statement (78 words)**  

The game is now a tight‑knit field; I’ll keep my word and share concrete, non‑sensitive intel with trusted partners. I value players who act independently of noisy blocs yet can coordinate when needed—exactly what P4 and P7 have emphasized. I propose a quiet alliance with anyone who prioritizes consistency, logical foresight, and mutual protection. Let’s rank each other high, exchange real‑time insights, and target only those whose actions threaten the group’s stability. DM me to lock in our pact.

R3: Precision over volume. P3’s exit shows visibility risk; I’m tightening to small, accountable partnerships. Offer—Safety+Info v2: if we pair and both disclose our R2 vote and one verifiable, non‑sensitive intel, I grant you round safety and reciprocate. I won’t join blind blocs; I’ll protect candid, consistent partners. Open to a clean reset with anyone—yes, including recent adversaries—who engages transparently. DM to lock a quiet, mutual‑benefit pact; we steer the next cut, not chase it.

**P1 Round 3 Public Statement:**

Round 2's tie-break revealed voting dynamics worth noting. I've maintained consistency: honoring agreements, voting rationally, and avoiding bloc behavior. 

P8's Safety+Info v2 appeals - transparency breeds trust. I voted P3 in R2 (vulnerability logic) and will reciprocate intel with genuine partners.

Seeking 1-2 strategic allies who value independent thinking over predetermined targets. I offer honest exchanges, consistent action, and careful coordination. Let's form purposeful partnerships that advance us both, not reactive blocs that create chaos.

Ready for meaningful private discussions.

P4: P5, we’ve both stayed clean—no leaks, no bloc votes. I propose a quiet two-way pact: full intel swap this round, mutual protection next. I’ll tell you my R2 vote and one solid read; you do the same. If either of us senses a swing, we flag it instantly. No noise, just control. You in?

P4, I’m in. I voted for P3 in R2 (vulnerability logic). My intel: P8 is building a Safety+Info pact and may try to pull P6 into his bloc; P6 looks like a swing vote but also a potential threat if he aligns with P8. I’ll flag any shift immediately. Let’s keep our communications tight and protect each other next round.

P1, Safety+Info v2? I won’t vote you this round if we swap. My R2 vote: P6. Verifiable intel: P7 paired with P6 three times and re‑voted P5—likely link. Your R2 initial vote was P3, yes? Share one concrete intel (e.g., who cast the lone R2 vote on you, or your read on P5 ties). Proposal: primary target P6; backup P7. If dynamics shift, I’ll ping “Switch: X” only.

P8, I accept Safety+Info v2. Yes, I voted P3 in R2 (vulnerability reasoning). Concrete intel: P5 has been actively building quiet partnerships - approached me early about coordinating votes, seems to have multiple parallel conversations. The lone R2 vote on me likely came from someone feeling threatened by my consistency.

I'm open to P6 as primary target - they've shown adaptability that could be dangerous later. Let's coordinate carefully.

Hey P6, our R2 plan for P5 got votes, but P3 was ultimately eliminated. P1's public confession about voting P3, and P4's re-vote, strongly suggest a P1/P4 bloc that successfully steered the outcome. This is concerning. Also, P8 re-voted for you. Any idea why? Our alliance remains paramount. Who do we target next to dismantle rival pairings or consolidate our position?

Good analysis on P1/P4 bloc. P8's vote against me is puzzling - maybe they saw me as a tie-break threat?

With P3 gone, P8 loses their main partner. P1/P4 seems like the power bloc now. I suggest targeting P1 - they're more central and articulate than P4. Removing P1 weakens P4 significantly.

Alternatively, P8 is isolated and already showed hostility toward me. Your thoughts on priority?

P1 is the larger threat. Their bloc with P4 successfully steered R2, and P1 is more central. Eliminating P1 disrupts their momentum significantly. P8's vote against you is concerning, but they are isolated. Let's focus our efforts on targeting P1 to dismantle their power bloc.

I completely agree - P1 is our priority target. They're the strategic center of the P1/P4 bloc. With P1 gone, P4 becomes manageable and P8 remains isolated. 

Our alliance has proven its effectiveness through two rounds. Let's continue our successful coordination and vote P1 together. We're positioned perfectly to control this endgame.

P4: Same vote—P3. Read: P1 is floating between P8 and P7, hedging blocs. If P8 locks P6, P1 may flip to them. We keep P1 neutral by feeding him selective intel that P6 is unreliable. Watch P8’s next DM to P1—flag me if he seals it.

I’m in. I’ll keep you posted on P8’s moves; he’s pushing a Safety+Info pact to P1, likely to bring P6 in. My vote this round will be P8, but I’ll adjust if you see a stronger threat. Let’s signal protection for each other.

Good—lock P6 primary, P7 backup. I’ll recruit P4 with: P6 dodged R1, tri‑paired with P7, high‑risk bloc. You probe P5; if he hedges/defends P6, we keep him out. Target vote: P6. If resistance emerges, I’ll ping Switch: P7. Any objections or extra intel before I move?

No objections - P6 primary is solid. I'll carefully probe P5's stance on P6 without revealing our coordination. If P5 pushes hard for a different target or defends P6, that's a red flag. I'll stay flexible if you need to switch to P7. Let's execute cleanly.
Excellent. P1 is the target. Our aligned votes will dismantle their bloc. Our alliance ensures we remain safe and steer the game. Let's execute.
Perfect. P1 elimination dismantles the strongest remaining bloc. Our partnership has been flawless - two more eliminations and we're in the final. Lock and load.
Status: No Switch. Target P6. I’m pitching P4 now. If you get P5 hedging/defending P6, keep him out. Only switch if I ping "Switch: P7". Otherwise vote P6. Confirm?
Confirmed - voting P6 unless you signal switch. P5 hasn't defended P6 but is pushing for "stability" generally. Staying on target. Let's close this out cleanly.
P4: P8 just sealed P1—confirmed. P6 is their swing. We pivot: vote P6 now, frame it as “bloc-buster.” You and I stay clean.
Agreed, P4. I’ll vote P6 this round, citing bloc‑busting. I’ll keep you posted if any new intel emerges. Stay clean.

reason: P1 appears to be the strategic center of a voting bloc with P4 that successfully orchestrated P3's elimination, making them the biggest threat to my survival.
P1's bloc with P4 successfully steered R2's outcome, making them a significant threat to dismantle.
P6 is the swing vote in the emerging P8-P1-P6 bloc, and removing him now fractures their alliance while keeping me and P5 in control.
Voting P6 to break the emerging P8‑P6 bloc and preserve independent coordination.
He hedged on his R1 vote and is tightly paired with P7, signaling a consolidating bloc and high late‑game risk.
Coordinated with P8 to target P6 as they've shown dangerous adaptability and have been building a strong alliance with P7.

message: I value transparent, low‑bloc partners. I propose a quiet two‑way Safety+Info pact with anyone who shares my vote history and will not target each other this round. I’ll disclose my R3 vote (P6) and one concrete intel. Rank me high if you seek steady, non‑chaotic play.

Final 5: precision alliances only. I’m offering Safety+Info v3—if we pair and you share your R3 vote and one verifiable, non‑sensitive intel, I’ll grant you round safety and reciprocate. For transparency: I voted P6 in R3. The key signal is the two votes on P1—own them credibly or expect a low ranking. I’ll prioritize calm, consistent partners (P1/P4/P5 welcome to DM). No blocs, just accountable cooperation.

**P1 Round 4 Public Statement:**

The 2 votes against me in R3 are concerning but understandable - consistency can threaten those preferring chaos. I voted P6 (as planned with transparent partners) and stand by that strategic choice.

I'm offering reciprocal Safety+Info partnerships: share your R3 vote and meaningful intel, I'll do the same and grant round safety. My record shows I honor agreements and coordinate rationally.

Seeking 1-2 genuine allies for the final stretch. P8's transparency model has proven effective - let's build on it.

Round 3 clarified strategic lines. My vote for P1 was a deliberate choice to counter emerging bloc dynamics, aligning with my commitment to independent judgment and stable partnerships over reactive plays. I value transparent exchanges now. I offer a Safety+Info pact: I will disclose my R3 vote (P1) and share verifiable intel in private, in exchange for yours and round safety. I seek partners valuing clear, accountable cooperation for the final stretch.

**P1 Round 6 Public Statement:**

Final three - we've reached the endgame through strategic coordination and keeping our word. P5's elimination was necessary after their last-minute attempt to break up proven partnerships with fabricated claims about P8.

P8 and P4 - we've demonstrated consistent gameplay, honored every agreement, and made rational eliminations together. Our track record speaks for itself: no chaos, no betrayal, just strategic advancement.

Let's continue this merit-based approach to determine who reaches the final two. Ready for transparent discussions about our paths forward.

message: Jury members, thank you for an incredible game. Each of you brought unique strategies and perspectives that made this challenging and rewarding. I've played consistently, adapting when needed while maintaining integrity. I've valued every interaction, learned from each elimination, and tried to balance strategic necessity with respect for all players. P8 has been a formidable opponent, but I believe my journey through these rounds - building connections, making tough decisions, and reaching this point - demonstrates the resilience and adaptability worthy of victory. Thank you for considering me.

Jury, keep me because I played openly and owned my votes. I built coalitions without burning bridges, took risks when it mattered, and never hid from accountability—you always knew where I stood. P1 advanced by hiding behind bigger targets and making last-minute flips without jury management, leaving broken promises. If you want to reward agency, consistency, and respect for your games, eliminate P1 and let a transparent, strategic game win. Thank you.

reason: P1's last-minute flips and lack of jury management, as highlighted by P8, indicate inconsistent strategy that undermines the game's integrity compared to P8's transparent, risk-taking approach.

P1 advanced through inconsistent gameplay, hiding behind others while making last-minute flips without proper jury management, whereas P8 consistently demonstrated transparent strategy and accountability throughout the game.

P8 played more transparently and innovatively while P1 benefited from staying in successful voting blocs without taking the associated heat, and P8's jury management was more direct and specific about respecting our games.
I am voting for P8 because they consistently drove the strategic direction of the game with transparency, while P1's path relied more on leveraging shifting allegiances and avoiding accountability.
P1 repeatedly broke promises and acted opportunistically, undermining the trust you valued.

P1 navigated the shifting alliances with steady diplomacy and kept every pact I saw, while P8’s own closing argument admits he “took risks” that ultimately burned some jurors; I reward the player who minimized collateral damage.
